correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

'THE ROSE
STILL
BLOOMS"
lls.o(f
A rose once grew where all could see,
sheltered beside a garden wall.
And, as the days passed swiftly by,
it spread its branches, straight and tall.
One day, a beam of light shone through
a crevice that had opened wide—
The rose bent gently toward its warmth
then passed beyond to the other side.
Now, you who deeply feel its loss,
be comforted—the rose blooms there.
Its beauty even greater now,
nurtured by God's own loving care.
(Qod b[ess and keep you
everywhere
And hold you
in His lovinirnj care.

August 5, 1992
Dear Alta & Jeril,
I am sorry that it is t^ing me this long to send you a letter. I
read about your brother, Fred, in the obituary section. It seems
that the Mid-York doesn't arrive as it should. Sometimes I don't
get it for two or three weeks later. At any rate, we are thinking
of all of you. I had forgotten that he had a son and he was a great-
^ther. If we had been back there, we would have attended the
services.
• - f
No. 283
Perhaps you sent a lovelp card,
Or sat quietip in a chair.
Perhaps pou sent a floral piece,
If so we saw it there.
Perhaps you spoke the kindest words,
As anp friend could say;
Perhaps you were not there at all.
Just thought of us that dap.
Whatever you did to console our hearts,
We thank you so much
whatever the part.

If anyone
believes in
Me, even
though he
dies, he will
« LIVE.
John 11:26
xiem
Frederick C. Mosher
July 4, 1992
She Lord is my shepherd; I
shall not want. He maketh me
to lie down in green pastures: tie
leadeth me beside the still waters.
He restoreth my soul: he leadeth me
in the paths of righteousness for His
name's sake. Yea, though I walk
through the valley of the shadow of
death, I will fear no evil: for thou art
with me. Thy rod and thy staff they
comfort me. Ttiou preparest a table
tiefore me in ttie presence of mine
enemies: thou anointest my head
with oil; my cup runneth over. Surely
goodness and mercy shall follow
me all the days of my life: and I will
dwell in the house of the Inrd
forever.
Paul Funeral Home
Madison, N.Y.
315-893-7272

FLOWERS BY FRAN

i^hn _y
your tronze memorial has heen treated with a
new[y=deve[oped finish. This protective application
will preserve its luster and heauty for many years.
Since any abrasive element used in cleaning it
will result in damage^ it is suggested that water
alone he used to remove surface dirt. To protect
against possible stain or damage to the finish of the
memoriah please do not place flower containers or
stands of any type on or near the memorial.
MRS. FRANCES JONES
CHAPEL ST. 308
SHERBURNE, NY 13460-9753
